titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Long Island Weekly Intelligencer subscription receipt 1977.625
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

did.unittitle: Long Island Weekly Intelligencer subscription receipt
did.abstract: This collection contains one 1806 receipt for a subscription to the Long Island Weekly Intelligencer for subscriber Michael Vandervoort.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of John Robinson, date unknown.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single item.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Long Island Weekly Intelligencer commenced publication on May 26, 1806, with William Robinson and William Little serving as publisher and editor, respectively. Robinson and Little were booksellers and stationers on the corner of Old Ferry and Fulton Streets in Brooklyn, N.Y. The paper was well supported by original material in poetry and prose, including serially published short stories. One of the newspaper's features was a listing of letters left in the Brooklyn Post Office. The paper ceased publication at the end of 1806 due to lack of support.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Long Island Weekly Intelligencer subscription receipt, 1806, 1977.625, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains a receipt for a subscription to the Long Island Weekly Intelligencer for subscriber Michael Vandervoort, dated December 25, 1806.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This item is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
